RANAWAY fromthe Subscriber, some time since,
lad named JAMES R. Towns, an apprentice to the
hoe Making business. He is about 90 years old,
fell grown for his age. Had on ard took with him
flue cloth coat and pantaets. and blue surtout, to-
kether with sundry other clothing. The above re-
yard will be paid to any person who will appre-


lend said boy, together with reasonable charges if
brought home. All persons are forbid harbourng


in at their peril. JAMES SIMPSON.

Mr. Buchanan MIR. Isacks and Major Eaton have
thought proper to bring my name before the public,
as that of person implicated, or in some way con-
cerned, in an attempt to induce General Jackson to
give certain pledge, pledges as to a certain ap
pointment would be his duty to make in the event
OF his election as President of the United States.
One consequence of the publications of these gen.
tlemen has been that they have given rise to tor
rent of abuse and calumny which has been directed
against me. 1t is not however for the purpose OF
avertng this polluted stream, of noticing those
who have cast in their mite of SANDER that l sit
down. My object is of higher nature desire to
domyself justice. and so far as my best recollection
and judgement, shall permit to spread the truth and
the whole truth before my fellow citizens. l do not
hope by any thing can say, however satisfactory
and conclusive, to propfate any of my enemies,
personal or political shall |, for that, any
other. purpose, turn from full and fair examination
of such parts of the letters of the gentlemen who
have imposed upon me this unpleasant duty. As re-
ates to myself, could have wished to have been
spared this appeal, but it is no longer matter oil
choice. l might have been persuaded to per-
init the errors and inaccuracies of Mr.. Buchanan
and Mr. isacks, arising from want of recollection,
to pass unnoticed and, from desire to be at peace
l might even have been contented to over look their
unkindness; but, when Major Eaton, on their shew
ing presumes to call me ''the negotiator," in what



ratiyey bound to speak, and | will speak that which
| do know to be true Let the blame and condem-
nation fall where it ought where it is merited but
not on me.


If these were not motives sufficiently powerful,
there is another which would determine An
effort is making by the use, and the abuse, of my
name, to wound the characters Of some Of our abiest
and most exalted citizens, and by accusations which
| believe to be unfounded and in which l am cer-
lla., kD-1 L.
ton; to cast them down from the height which they
have honouraby attained and in their places to put
those whom regard as having adopted princi plies
and avowing determination to pursue course
of policy, which have no doubt would greatly af
feet the prosperity and happiness Of the State Of
Pennsylvania and of the whole Union.


That was originally friendly to the election o
General Jackson to the Presidency do not deny
My feelings of gratitude towards him for his militia
ry service to this country remain, and shall
main unchanged. | voted for him in the Democra

THE STOCKHOLDERS in this institution are


hereby notified, that an instalment OF rye Doars on


every share of the capital stock, VIII be due ana


payable on Thursday the 9Th day of November next,

~ lie fUHLlC.. II


Mr. Buchanan MIR. Isacks and Major Eaton have
thought proper to bring my name before the public,
as that of person implicated, or in some way con-
cerned, in an attempt to induce General Jackson to
give certain pledge, pledges as to a certain ap
pointment would be his duty to make in the event
OF his election as President of the United States.
One consequence of the publications of these gen.
tlemen has been that they have given rise to tor
rent of abuse and calumny which has been directed
against me. 1t is not however for the purpose OF
avertng this polluted stream, of noticing those
who have cast in their mite of SANDER that l sit
down. My object is of higher nature desire to
domyself justice. and so far as my best recollection
and judgement, shall permit to spread the truth and
the whole truth before my fellow citizens. l do not
hope by any thing can say, however satisfactory
and conclusive, to propfate any of my enemies,
personal or political shall |, for that, any
other. purpose, turn from full and fair examination
of such parts of the letters of the gentlemen who
have imposed upon me this unpleasant duty. As re-
ates to myself, could have wished to have been
spared this appeal, but it is no longer matter oil
choice. l might have been persuaded to per-
init the errors and inaccuracies of Mr.. Buchanan
and Mr. isacks, arising from want of recollection,
to pass unnoticed and, from desire to be at peace
l might even have been contented to over look their
unkindness; but, when Major Eaton, on their shew
ing presumes to call me ''the negotiator," in what



ratiyey bound to speak, and | will speak that which
| do know to be true Let the blame and condem-
nation fall where it ought where it is merited but
not on me.


If these were not motives sufficiently powerful,
there is another which would determine An
effort is making by the use, and the abuse, of my
name, to wound the characters Of some Of our abiest
and most exalted citizens, and by accusations which
| believe to be unfounded and in which l am cer-

ton; to cast them down from the height which they

those whom regard as having adopted princi plies
and avowing determination to pursue course
of policy, which have no doubt would greatly af
feet the prosperity and happiness Of the State Of
Pennsylvania and of the whole Union.
